content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays two large cross-sections of the colon. Both sections show a large, deeply infiltrating tumor, which appears as a dark, basophilic, and irregular mass disrupting the normal layered architecture of the bowel wall. The tumor appears to extend deep into the wall. Several round, purple structures resembling lymphoid aggregates are also visible within the bowel wall and possibly in the surrounding fatty tissue. The primary task here seems to be assessing the depth of invasion for T-staging.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this specific area because it represents the invasive front of the tumor at the interface with the muscularis propria (the thick, pink muscle layer of the bowel wall). Determining the relationship between the tumor and the muscularis propria is crucial for accurate T-staging. This view will help me assess whether the tumor is confined to the submucosa (pT1), invading the muscularis propria (pT2), or extending through the muscularis propria into the subserosal/pericolic tissue (pT3). The green box is positioned perfectly to evaluate this critical interface. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see two distinct tissue types. On the right, there are irregular, back-to-back glandular structures with dark, atypical nuclei, which are characteristic of adenocarcinoma. On the left, there are bundles of eosinophilic (pink) smooth muscle, representing the muscularis propria. The malignant glands are clearly seen infiltrating between and disrupting the smooth muscle bundles, accompanied by an inflammatory and desmoplastic (fibrous) stromal reaction. My impression is that this is a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that is actively invading the muscularis propria. This finding confirms a tumor stage of at least pT2.
